M.G.L. c. 208, \u00a7 28.proposition: M.G.L. c. 208, § 28 asserts that the child’s well-being is paramount in all custody decisions. When circumstances materially change, such as unsafe behavior by a parent, custody must be revisited in the best interests of the minor child.

M.G.L. c. 209C, \u00a7 20.proposition: This Court has jurisdiction over this matter pursuant to M.G.L. c. 209C, § 20, regarding modifications of custody orders involving minor children.

Massachusetts c. 90, \u00a7 24.proposition: See Massachusetts c. 90, § 24 prohibiting operation of a motor vehicle under the influence of alcohol or drugs.

*Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas*, 395 Mass..proposition: The Massachusetts Supreme Judicial Court has long recognized that the “best interests of the child” is the touchstone for custody determinations and modifications.
*Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas*, 395 Mass..support_reasoning: The opinion explicitly interprets the removal statute’s phrase “upon cause shown” to mean that removal must be in the “best interests of the child,” and then repeatedly characterizes the “best interests” standard as the central and paramount concern in deciding custody-related issues. Although this case is in the specific context of removal after divorce, the court treats best interests as the governing touchstone for custody determinations, consistent with long-standing Massachusetts law, and cites earlier SJC precedent (Rubin) to that effect.
*Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas*, 395 Mass..relevant_excerpt: “The Massachusetts removal statute, G. L. c. 208, § 30 (1984 ed.), provides that … ‘unless the court upon cause shown otherwise orders.’ The words ‘upon cause shown’ mean only that removal must be in the best interests of the child (Rubin v. Rubin, 370 Mass. 857 [1976]; Hale v. Hale, supra at 815), and thus the central question in this case is how these ‘best interests’ are to be determined… Although the best interests of the children always remain the paramount concern…”

*Rosenthal v. Maney*, 51 Mass. App. Ct..proposition: The Massachusetts Supreme Judicial Court has long recognized that the “best interests of the child” is the touchstone for custody determinations and modifications.
*Rosenthal v. Maney*, 51 Mass. App. Ct..support_reasoning: This is a Massachusetts Appeals Court decision, not a Supreme Judicial Court (SJC) opinion, so it cannot itself demonstrate what the SJC has "long recognized." While the opinion repeatedly applies a best-interests standard and cites SJC precedents (e.g., Hersey, Yannas), it does not itself stand as SJC authority for the historical proposition attributed to the SJC. Thus it supports use of best interests in custody determinations, but not the specific claim about longstanding SJC recognition.
*Rosenthal v. Maney*, 51 Mass. App. Ct..relevant_excerpt: Our decision today, that a request for modification of custody is distinct from a request to relocate and must be based on a material and substantial change in circumstances other than the move, is consistent with these decisions and with G. L. c. 208, § 28 ("the court may make a judgment modifying its earlier judgment as to the care and custody of the minor children of the parties provided that the court finds that a material and substantial change in circumstances of the. parties has occurred and the judgment of modification is necessary in the best interests of the children").

*Hunter v. Rose*, 463 Mass. 488 (2012).proposition: Defendant’s behavior creates an unsafe environment and threatens Ethan’s emotional security as contemplated under *Hunter v. Rose*, 463 Mass. 488 (2012), which emphasizes physical safety in determining fitness of parental custodial access.
*Hunter v. Rose*, 463 Mass. 488 (2012).support_reasoning: The opinion applies a broad “best interests of the child” standard and considers whether living conditions adversely affect a child’s physical, mental, moral, or emotional health, but it does not “emphasize physical safety” as a distinct or primary factor in determining parental fitness or custodial access. The focus is on emotional bonds, stability, continuity of care, and one parent’s alienating behavior—not on physical danger or an “unsafe environment” in the sense implied by the proposition. Thus, citing Hunter v. Rose for an emphasis on physical safety in evaluating fitness for custodial access misstates the case’s holding and reasoning.
*Hunter v. Rose*, 463 Mass. 488 (2012).relevant_excerpt: “The judge shall consider ‘whether or not the child’s present or past living conditions adversely affect his physical, mental, moral or emotional health.’ G. L. c. 208, § 31. Factors a judge may weigh are whether one parent’s home is more stable in terms of a parent’s work schedule, whether siblings are being raised together, and whether one parent seeks to undermine the relationship a child has with the other parent.”

*Mason v. Coleman*, 447 Mass. 177, 185 (.proposition: There is a body of Massachusetts case law underscoring a parent’s substance abuse as a material and substantial change in circumstances.
*Mason v. Coleman*, 447 Mass. 177, 185 (.support_reasoning: The opinion in Mason v. Coleman concerns standards for removal of children from the Commonwealth when parents share joint legal and physical custody, and discusses relocation as a substantial change in circumstances in the ALI Principles quotation. It does not address parental substance abuse at all, nor does it characterize substance abuse as a material and substantial change. Therefore it cannot be cited as authority for a body of Massachusetts case law underscoring a parent’s substance abuse as a material change.
*Mason v. Coleman*, 447 Mass. 177, 185 (.relevant_excerpt:
“The Principles of the Law of Family Dissolution § 2.17 (2002)… state in pertinent part:
‘(1) The relocation of a parent constitutes a substantial change in circumstances… only when the relocation significantly impairs either parent’s ability to exercise responsibilities…’”
